title: Octadrachm (Coin) Portraying Queen Arsinoe II
transcript:
Narrator: On this golden coin we see the profile of Arsinoe II, who was queen of Egypt during the Ptolemaic period. Curator Ashley Arico.

Ashley Arico: The Ptolemaic Dynasty in Ancient Egypt was the longest ruling of Egypt’s dynastic families. It was part of a period of Greek rule in Egypt, which started when Alexander the Great, King of Macedon, who conquered Egypt in 332 BC.

Narrator: When Alexander died he had no clear successor, so his empire was divided up with Egypt going to his childhood friend and general Ptolemy.

Ashley: So it’s his direct decedents who make up the rest of the Ptolemaic Dynasty.

Arsinoe as a person is kind of interesting, because she was a very powerful woman who clearly sought out power.

Narrator: This search for power began as early as her teenage years when she was married to the ruler Lysimachus.

Ashley: The story goes that to help secure her children’s position in the line of succession, she had his son by his first wife executed for treason.

Narrator: And then there was the time with her second husband, Ptolemy Keraunos.

Ashley: She also tries to overthrow him, but he finds out about it and has her two younger sons executed and Arsinoe is exiled to Egypt.

Narrator: By her third husband, Arisone may have been ready to settle down, and what better way to do that than by keeping it in the family?

Ashley: It’s at this point that she marries her full brother, Ptolemy II.

Narrator: If you could flip this coin over, you’d actually find a hint at this familial marriage. On the back side you would find two names, Arsinoe and Philadelphus, meaning sibling loving.

Ultimately, Arsinoe was worshiped throughout Egypt after Ptolemy decreed that she and their parents were gods.

Ashley: So this coin we’re looking at here is actually issued after Arsinoe’s death, which is somewhat unusual for a coin depicting a ruler, but by this time she’s been elevated to the position of not just a queen but a goddess.
